messages.content: I want to find 5 corporate sponsors in the Chicago area that may be interested in supporting a deaf refugee nonprofit 501c3 organization, can you help

I'd be happy to help you identify potential corporate sponsors in the Chicago area for your deaf refugee nonprofit organization. Here are five companies that have a history of supporting community initiatives, and may be interested in partnering with your 501(c)(3) organization:

1. Boeing:
As a global aerospace company with a strong presence in Chicago, Boeing has a long history of corporate citizenship and philanthropy. They have a focus on supporting causes related to education, veterans, and community engagement. You can find more information on their website: https://www.boeing.com/principles/community-engagement.page

2. Allstate:
This insurance company, headquartered in the Chicago area, has a strong commitment to giving back to the community. Allstate supports a variety of causes, including those related to empowering youth, disaster relief, and creating safe communities. Visit their corporate responsibility page for more information: https://corporate.allstate.com/corporate-responsibility.aspx

3. United Airlines:
With its headquarters in Chicago, United Airlines is another potential sponsor for your nonprofit. Their charitable giving focuses on education, environment, and community well-being. They also have a history of supporting initiatives related to diversity and inclusion. Explore their community engagement page for more details: https://www.united.com/ual/en/us/fly/company/global-citizenship.html

4. Exelon Corporation:
Exelon is a leading energy company based in Chicago. They have a long-standing commitment to supporting local communities through grants and employee volunteerism. Their focus areas include education, environment, and community development. To learn more about their community programs, visit: https://www.exeloncorp.com/community/giving-and-grants

5. McDonald's Corporation:
As a global fast-food company with its headquarters in Chicago, McDonald's has an extensive history of philanthropy and community involvement. They support a range of causes, including education, children's health, and disaster relief. You can find more about their charitable efforts on their website: https://www.mcdonalds.com/us/en-us/community/giving-back.html

Before approaching these companies, I recommend doing further research on their specific philanthropic interests and guidelines to ensure your organization aligns with their mission and values. Good luck with your search for corporate sponsors!
Can you find smaller corporations that may be interested as well, keep it to five

Certainly! Here are five smaller corporations based in the Chicago area that may be interested in supporting your deaf refugee nonprofit organization:

1. Groupon:
Groupon is a Chicago-based e-commerce marketplace that connects subscribers with local merchants. They have a history of supporting local nonprofits and community initiatives through their Groupon Grassroots program. You can find more information about their community involvement on their website: https://about.groupon.com/groupon-cares/

2. Grubhub:
Grubhub is a Chicago-based online and mobile food-ordering and delivery marketplace. They have a commitment to giving back to their communities through various philanthropic initiatives, including supporting local nonprofits. Learn more about their community engagement here: https://www.grubhub.com/about/corporate_social_responsibility

3. Basecamp:
Basecamp is a Chicago-based software company that creates project management and team collaboration tools. They are known for supporting local nonprofits and charitable organizations. You can find more information about their community involvement and how to reach out to them on their website: https://basecamp.com/about/public-benefit

4. Radio Flyer:
Radio Flyer is a Chicago-based company known for their iconic red wagons and other outdoor toys. They support community organizations and nonprofits through their Radio Flyer Smile Makers program, which focuses on children's well-being, education, and health. Learn more about their philanthropy efforts here: https://www.radioflyer.com/smile-makers

5. Guaranteed Rate:
Guaranteed Rate is a Chicago-based mortgage company that actively supports local communities and nonprofit organizations. Their Guaranteed Rate Foundation is dedicated to providing financial assistance to individuals and families in need. To learn more about their charitable initiatives, visit their website: https://www.guaranteedrate.com/about-gr-foundation

Before approaching these smaller corporations, I recommend researching their specific philanthropic interests and guidelines to ensure your organization aligns with their mission and values. Good luck with your search for corporate sponsors!
